title: Requires licenses for administrators of product warranties
summary: Prohibits any person from acting as an administrator of warranties on motor vehicles or mechanical or electronic appliances unless such person has been licensed by the insurance department; adds new article to the insurance law entitled "administration of product warranties"; outlines covered requirements, provides penalties for violations and authorizes the insurance department to promulgate necessary rules and regulations.

BILL NUMBER:S2218

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the insurance law, in relation to licensing requirements
for persons who offer warranties for motor vehicles and appliances

PURPOSE/SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill requires administrators of product warranty contracts to
obtain an administrator's license from the Insurance Department after
showing: 1) experience and competence in the business; 2) minimum net
worth of $150,000; and 3) a contract liability policy from a New York
insurer indemnifying the administrators, the seller and the purchaser
of the service contract in the event of loss or depletion of the
claims reserve account held by the administrator. This bill adds a
new article to the Insurance Law (21-A) entitled "Administration of
Product Warranties." The new article defines the covered
requirements, provides penalties for violations, and requires the
Insurance Department to promulgate regulations to implement the
provisions of the article.

JUSTIFICATION:
At the present time, New York consumers can purchase product warranty
coverage against manufacturers' defects. The most common item covered
is an automobile, although more recently coverage is available for
large appliances like televisions, washing machines, refrigerators,
freezers, home computers, etc. The consumer pays the retailer in
advance for this coverage. The retailer in turn pays a service
contract company to administer the claims during the term of the
contract. During the last few years, some service contract
administrators have been improperly managed, forcing at least three
large contract administrators into bankruptcy. In each instance.,
there was insufficient backup insurance and/or reserves to honor
consumer claims under the contract, thus shortchanging New York
consumers. This bill will rectify the situation by requiring adequate
backup insurance to honor consumer claims.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
To the extent that licensing fees do not cover the Department's cost
of reviewing and issuing an administrator's license, there may be a
slight impact on the insurance industry which pays the cost of
running the Insurance Department. There is no fiscal impact to the
State.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the first of January after it shall have
become a law.
